G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: 3. This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, § 19 as the damages sought do not exceed $50,000, and venue is proper under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the property at issue is located in Lowell, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: 3. This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, § 19 as the damages sought do not exceed $50,000, and venue is proper under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the property at issue is located in Lowell, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: 14. Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant, as a landlord, is prohibited from interfering with the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.

*Davis v. Inspector of Bldgs. of Waterto.raw_text: *Davis v. Inspector of Bldgs. of Watertown*, 387 Mass. 37, 39 (1982)
*Davis v. Inspector of Bldgs. of Waterto.proposition: 15. The mold, caused by ventilation issues in the bathroom that Defendant failed to remedy, constitutes a serious and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s right to use and enjoy the premises.
*Davis v. Inspector of Bldgs. of Waterto.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns tax classification and valuation of agricultural/horticultural land and the Appellate Tax Board’s jurisdiction over consolidated tax appeals. It does not address landlord-tenant law, habitability, mold, ventilation, or interference with use and enjoyment of residential premises. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that mold from bathroom ventilation issues constitutes a serious and unreasonable interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
*Davis v. Inspector of Bldgs. of Waterto.relevant_excerpt: The case is entirely about tax classification and valuation, not housing conditions. For example: “We must decide whether, by taking a single appeal from two decisions of the assessors concerning similar and contiguous parcels, the taxpayer committed a procedural error sufficient to deprive the board of jurisdiction to decide any or all of the three appeals.” This does not relate to mold, ventilation, or interference with use and enjoyment of premises.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: 15. The mold, caused by ventilation issues in the bathroom that Defendant failed to remedy, constitutes a serious and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s right to use and enjoy the premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with interference from drug-related criminal activity in common areas and analyzes statutory duties, warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, and nuisance. It does not address mold, ventilation issues, or other physical conditions inside a unit, nor does it characterize such conditions as a serious and unreasonable interference with use and enjoyment. The only discussion of "serious interference" relates to criminal activity in common areas, not indoor environmental conditions like mold, so this citation does not support the specific mold-based proposition.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.proposition: 16. Defendant’s blame-shifting and refusal to appropriately address the conditions, despite notice from Plaintiff, constitutes a constructive eviction and an actionable violation of Massachusetts law.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, covenant of quiet enjoyment, retaliation, and G.L. c. 93A, but it does not frame the landlord’s conduct as a constructive eviction or analyze constructive eviction doctrine. The tenant did move out, but the court’s reasoning is in terms of statutory and common-law habitability, emotional distress, and consumer protection, not constructive eviction based on ‘blame-shifting and refusal to appropriately address conditions.’ Thus the case does not provide authority for the specific constructive eviction proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.relevant_excerpt:
After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; ... and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.... The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects....

In late August, 1983, an inspector reinspected the apartment... The inspector found that virtually all of the defects identified by the judge remained unrepaired.... On September 9, 1983, the inspector again made an inspection of the premises and reported that unrepaired defects remained. Gonzalez moved out of the apartment on September 15, 1983.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.proposition: 16. Defendant’s blame-shifting and refusal to appropriately address the conditions, despite notice from Plaintiff, constitutes a constructive eviction and an actionable violation of Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that the landlord’s reckless failure to remedy repeated flooding, after notice, violates the implied warranty of habitability and G.L. c. 186, § 14, and supports recovery for emotional distress. However, the opinion does not characterize the conduct as a ‘constructive eviction,’ nor does it hold that such blame-shifting and refusal to address conditions, by themselves, amount to constructive eviction. The support is for statutory and tort remedies (habitability, quiet enjoyment, emotional distress), not for a constructive eviction doctrine as phrased in the proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment. … [W]e hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.proposition: 16. Defendant’s blame-shifting and refusal to appropriately address the conditions, despite notice from Plaintiff, constitutes a constructive eviction and an actionable violation of Massachusetts law.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord’s failure to correct conditions within its control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction under Massachusetts law. However, it does not involve or discuss a tenant-defendant, "blame-shifting," or a defendant’s refusal to address conditions; instead, it concerns landlords’ liability and tenants successfully asserting constructive eviction as a defense to rent. Thus, it supports the general constructive-eviction principle, but not the specific proposition as framed about a defendant’s conduct.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 71.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: 17. Plaintiff has suffered damages, including harm to her health, property loss, and emotional distress, as a result of Defendant’s actions and omissions.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns landlord-tenant disputes over security deposits, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability, and allocation of utility obligations. It does not discuss a plaintiff suffering health damage, property loss, or emotional distress as elements of recoverable damages, nor does it analyze standards for such damages. Thus, it does not provide authority for the broad damages proposition stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the "percentage reduction approach" in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: 11. Defendant’s refusal to remedy the mold issue and address the inadequate ventilation interferes with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment of the premises.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent in Hemingway) concerns implied warranty of habitability and the effect of housing code violations on rent obligations and eviction, not interference with the covenant/right of quiet enjoyment. The quoted section does not discuss mold, ventilation, or quiet enjoyment, nor does it articulate a standard for when conditions constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. It is therefore not proper authority for the specific proposition that refusal to remedy mold and inadequate ventilation interferes with quiet enjoyment.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The net result of this court’s interpretation of these statutes was (a) that the owner of a dwelling unit which did not comply with the prescribed minimum standards could be prosecuted criminally, (b) that if he rented the unit without correcting the violations the statutes did not per se impose an obligation on him for the benefit of the tenant to correct the violations, and (c) that unless there was an express agreement to the contrary, the tenant took the unit subject to all existing violations and if he wanted them corrected the burden of doing so was on him.”

*Binder v. Mechanic*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: 11. Defendant’s refusal to remedy the mold issue and address the inadequate ventilation interferes with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment of the premises.
*Binder v. Mechanic*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is about attorney retainers, fee reasonableness, and a client’s right to discharge counsel; it does not involve landlord‑tenant law, habitability, or interference with quiet enjoyment of residential premises. Nothing in the case discusses mold, ventilation, or any conditions of leased property. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority that a landlord’s refusal to remedy mold or ventilation problems interferes with a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
*Binder v. Mechanic*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Essential to the lawyer-client relationship is the client’s right to change his lawyer at any time — even without cause… A discharged lawyer who has not rendered substantial performance cannot recover on a contingent fee contract, but may only seek a reasonable fee on a quantum meruit basis.” (Binder v. Mechanic, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 21, 23-24 (1985).)

*King v. G&M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 65.proposition: 15. The mold, caused by ventilation issues in the bathroom that Defendant failed to remedy, constitutes a serious and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s right to use and enjoy the premises.
*King v. G&M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 65.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G&M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 65.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a tenant’s negligence claim for injuries from a defective common stairway and the scope of a landlord’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas. It does not address mold, ventilation issues, or whether such conditions constitute a serious and unreasonable interference with use and enjoyment of the premises (i.e., a nuisance or habitability-type claim). Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about mold constituting interference with the tenant’s enjoyment of the premises.
*King v. G&M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 65.relevant_excerpt: “We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors… The landlord should not be allowed to remain in such a position that he has no incentive to maintain the areas retained under his control in reasonably safe condition….”
